title: User-Centered Design
description: Applying NN/g usability heuristics to create intuitive, accessible interfaces

principles.title: Visibility of System Status
principles.description: The system should always keep users informed about what is going on, through appropriate feedback within reasonable time. If the user is asking "is something happening?", the system is failing this principle. If, however, the system consistently understands what is happening, when, and with what outcome, Visibility of System Status is respected.

principles.title: Match Between the System and the Real World
principles.description: The system should speak the users' language, with words, phrases and concepts familiar to the user, rather than system-oriented terms.

principles.title: User Control and Freedom
principles.description: Users often choose system functions by mistake and will need a clearly marked 'emergency exit' to leave the unwanted state without having to go through an extended dialogue.

principles.title: Consistency and Standards
principles.description: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing. Follow platform conventions.

principles.title: Error Prevention
principles.description: Even better than good error messages is a careful design which prevents a problem from occurring in the first place.

principles.title: Recognition Rather than Recall
principles.description: Minimize the user's memory load by making objects, actions, and options visible. The user should not have to remember information from one part of the dialogue to another.

principles.title: Flexibility and Efficiency of Use
principles.description: Accelerators, unseen by the novice user, may often speed up the interaction for the expert user such that the system can cater to both inexperienced and experienced users.

principles.title: Aesthetic and Minimalist Design
principles.description: Dialogues should not contain information which is irrelevant or rarely needed. Every extra unit of information in a dialogue competes with the relevant units of information and diminishes their relative visibility.

principles.title: Help Users Recognize, Diagnose, and Recover from Errors
principles.description: Error messages should be expressed in plain language (no codes), precisely indicate the problem, and constructively suggest a solution.

principles.title: Help and Documentation
principles.description: Even though it is better if the system can be used without documentation, it may be necessary to provide help and documentation.

bibliography.author: Meganne Ohata
bibliography.title: Match Between System and Real World
bibliography.description: The design should speak the users’ language. Use words, phrases, and concepts familiar to the user, rather than internal jargon. Follow real-world conventions, making information appear in a natural and logical order.

bibliography.author: Aurora Harley
bibliography.title: Visibility of System Status (Usability Heuristic #1)
bibliography.description: Communicating the current state allows users to feel in control of the system, take appropriate actions to reach their goal, and ultimately trust the brand.

bibliography.author: Anna Kaley
bibliography.title: Match Between the System and the Real World (Usability Heuristic #2)
bibliography.description: Systems should speak the users' language with familiar words, phrases, and concepts rather than system-oriented terms. Interfaces that follow real-world conventions and make information appear in a natural and logical order demonstrate empathy and acknowledgement for users.

bibliography.author: Maria Rosala
bibliography.title: User Control and Freedom (Usability Heuristic #3)
bibliography.description: Users often make mistakes or change their minds. Allow them to exit a flow or undo their last action and go back to the system’s previous state.

bibliography.author: Rachel Krause
bibliography.title: Maintain Consistency and Adhere to Standards (Usability Heuristic #4)
bibliography.description: Users should not have to wonder whether different words, situations, or actions mean the same thing. Follow platform and industry conventions.

bibliography.author: Katie Sherwin
bibliography.title: Usability Heuristic 5: Error Prevention
bibliography.description: No. 5 of the top 10 UX design heuristics is to prevent interaction problems from occurring in the first place: either eliminate error-prone conditions or check for them and present users with a confirmation dialog.

bibliography.author: Page Laubheimer
bibliography.title: Flexibility and Efficiency of Use (Usability Heuristic #7)
bibliography.description: Shortcuts — unseen by the novice user — speed up the interaction for the expert users such that the system can cater to both inexperienced and experienced users.

bibliography.author: Therese Fessenden
bibliography.title: Aesthetic and Minimalist Design (Usability Heuristic #8)
bibliography.description: Aesthetically pleasing designs can provide memorable experiences that differentiate a brand. However, interfaces should only include necessary elements, with high informational value. Clarity will always win over visual flourish.

bibliography.author: Alita Kendrick
bibliography.title: Help and Documentation (Usability Heuristic #10)
bibliography.description: Interface help comes in two forms: proactive and reactive. Proactive help is intended to get users familiar with an interface while reactive help is meant for troubleshooting and gaining system proficiency.

bibliography.description: What makes a design look messy and unprofessional? More often than not, it's a lack of visual hierarchy—a structured way to guide the user’s eye through an interface.
